block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

Bombs Sweep Baghdad; Monthly U.S. Toll Tops 100 A spasm of violence seized Baghdad, as 46 Iraqis were killed in six bombings across the city and a moderate Sunni Arab figure was gunned down by two men on motorcycles. The American toll for October rose to 102, the highest since January 2005. A1

Chad Raids Mirror Darfur's Attacks deep inside Chad over the past month echoed raids in the war-ravaged Darfur region of Sudan, but were carried out by Chadian Arabs, not Sudanese as in previous attacks, the victims said. The fact that the attackers were local raised fears of a broader, regional conflict. A3

Pakistan Bombs Islamic School The Pakistani military said that it had destroyed a religious school near the Afghan border in a raid, killing at least 80 people it described as militants. Among those reported killed was Maulvi Liaqut, a cleric whom the authorities have accused of sheltering local and foreign militants. A6

Israel May Widen Gaza Actions Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said that Israel may expand military operations in the Gaza Strip, but that it has no intention of reoccupying the territory. A Palestinian militant was killed in Gaza in disputed circumstances. A8

British Warn on Global Warming A report commissioned by the British government warned that failure to act swiftly on global warming will have a cataclysmic effect on the global economy. The report also predicted apocalyptic effects from climate change. A8

Pilot Said to Ignore Warning The pilot of a commercial jet that crashed in Nigeria, killing 96 people, had ignored crucial warnings from air traffic controllers about the dangerous stormy weather, aviation officials in Nigeria said. A3
NATIONAL A16-22

State Legislature Races Look Good for Democrats More than 6,000 state legislative offices in 46 states are on the ballot next week, and as in the seismic elections of 1994 and 1974 their cumulative impact could be immense. Democrats are favored to take control of a majority of state capitals for the first time in a decade.
A1

Michigan Weighs Race as Issue A ballot proposition would amend Michigan's Constitution to ban public institutions from considering race or sex in public education, employment or contracting. Polls show voters split on the matter.
A1

New Breed of Dogs for Veterans While veterans who lose their sight or hearing or must use a wheelchair have long had service dogs as companions, dogs around the country are now being trained to work with people who use both a wheelchair and prosthetics to get around. A16

Red Cross to Cut Board Size The American Red Cross, which has come under fire for its response to Hurricane Katrina, announced plans to sharply cut back the size and management role of its 50-member board.

Nevada to Vote on Smoking Ban In Nevada, antismoking sentiment appears ready to trump the anything-goes lifestyle. Next week, voters will decide two ballot measures would that restrict where people can smoke.
EDUCATION

Deaf Students Renew Demands After protesters at Gallaudet University, the world's premier university for the deaf, prevailed in ousting the incoming president, they pressed forward with more demands, saying the next choice should be a more forceful advocate for deaf culture and a strong deaf identity. A17
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8

In Cuomo's Quest for Post, Father Plays a Subtle Role No one has been more personally invested in Andrew Cuomo's quest for office than his father, former Governor Mario M. Cuomo, who has worked relentlessly behind the scenes to resurrect, rehabilitate and return the family name to power after his own exile from the governor's mansion 12 years ago. A1

Iraq Returns to Senate Race Ned Lamont, returning to the issue that won him the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in August, has begun intensifying his attacks on Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut over the Iraq war. B1
SCIENCE TIMES F1-10

Fossils Found of a Big Bird Fossils of the largest known bird, an extinct flightless predator with a skull the size of a horse's and a menacing beak like an eagle's, have been discovered in Argentina, paleontologists reported last week. F3
Health & Fitness F5
ARTS E1-10

Whitney Expansion May Move The Whitney Museum of American Art, after fighting for more than a year to have an addition to its Madison Avenue building approved, has all but decided that moving its expansion to another site would make more sense, people involved in the process say. E1
OBITUARIES A22-23
Richard Gilman A drama and literary critic whose voice resonated through four decades in American letters, he was 83. A22
BUSINESS DAY C1-12
U.S. Drops Claim vs. Chevron The Interior Department has dropped claims that the Chevron Corporation systematically underpaid the government for natural gas produced in the Gulf of Mexico.
A1
Business Digest C2
EDITORIAL A24-25
Editorials: The untracked guns of Iraq; assessing the damages; pay to obey; making meals count in New York.
Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof.
